findings: This feature consistently activates across large genes encoding RTX toxin-related proteins and Ca2+-binding domains. In Desulfomicrobium baculatum examples (sections 0, 1, 2), the strongest activations occur within very large Ca2+-binding RTX toxin-related genes. In other organisms, activations correlate with secretion system components, particularly those involved in type II, IV, and VII secretion pathways. conclusion: This feature robustly detects RTX toxin-related proteins and secretion system components across diverse bacterial species.
title: RTX toxin and secretion system detector
description: This feature detects large genes encoding RTX toxin-related proteins and various bacterial secretion system components. It shows distributed activation throughout these genes rather than at specific boundaries or motifs. RTX (Repeats in ToXin) proteins contain characteristic glycine-rich nonapeptide repeats that bind calcium ions and are often associated with type I secretion systems. The consistent activation across diverse bacterial species (particularly Desulfomicrobium baculatum) suggests this feature detects conserved sequence characteristics of these large, repetitive toxin genes and related secretion machinery. The biological function relates to bacterial toxin production and secretion, which are important virulence factors in many bacterial pathogens.
